clinical_study.brief_title: Biofilm Modified Macrophage Phenotype and Function in Diabetic Wound Healing
clinical_study.official_title: Biofilm Modified Macrophage Phenotype and Function in Diabetic Wound Healing

brief_summary.textblock: The aim is to study the microenvironment of chronic biofilm infection in diabetic wounds which shows deregulated immune cells responses and biofilm interaction resulting in delayed/impaired/non wound healing. We seek to understand immune evasion strategy of biofilms and study mechanisms which biofilm modify macrophages phenotype and functions in such wounds

detailed_description.textblock:
Specific Objective:
1. Determine if functionally active macrophage isolated from biofilm-infected diabetic wounds show extra cellular matrix degrading phenotype causing wound collagen degradation
2. Understand by investigating whether increased presence of ECM degrading wound macrophage phenotypes in biofilm infected human diabetic wounds are associated with reduced wound collagen levels and increased wound recurrence End goal will be to understand the mechanism in which biofilm modulates the wound macrophage phenotype and function

primary_outcome.measure: Assess macrophage phenotype and functional modification due to biofilm infection in diabetic patients
primary_outcome.time_frame: One and half year for complete results
primary_outcome.description: Wound tissue macrophage will undergo a series of laboratory studies including: flow cytometry, Immunophnotyping, cytokine assays (pg/ml), and ELISA (pg/ml)

secondary_outcome.measure: Characterize difference between wound macrophages and macrophages derived from peripheral blood in diabetic patients
secondary_outcome.description: Mechanism responsible for downregulated wound inflammatory cell function in patients with diabetes.This will be assessed through immunohistochemistry (IHC) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).

arm_group.description: Diabetic patients with HbA1c<9 with who have wound 4weeks or longer with infection with following interventions: Finger prick test for HbA1c measurement Punch biopsy VAC sponge collection Ankle brachial index

Diabetic patients with HbA1c<9 who have wound 4 weeks or longer without infection with following interventions: Finger prick test for HbA1c measurement Punch biopsy VAC sponge collection Ankle brachial index

intervention.intervention_name: Finger prick test for HbA1c measurement
intervention.description: HbA1c measurement with finger prick method
Wound site will be anaesthetized, by punch biopsy tissue will be collected, wound site will be monitored for bleeding(if bleeding Cautery will be used to stop bleeding).
NPWT sponge which is discarded as biological waste, will be collected for wound macrophage isolation

biospec_descr.textblock: Blood, Wound Vac Sponge, Wound Tissue biopsy

study_pop.textblock: 28 diabetic subjects with chronic foot ulcer(s) that are receiving Negative Wound Pressure Therapy (NPWT) will be enrolled. 18 subjects will be infected and 10 subjects will be non-infected serving as the control for the study. The inclusion and exclusion criteria were carefully selected to enroll diabetic patients who have wound tissue oxygenation adequate to support wound healing.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age 18 - 70 years old
2. Willing and able to provide informed consent
3. Willing and able to comply with protocol instructions, including biopsies and study visits
4. Diabetics with HbA1c ≤ 9
5. Chronic (open ≥ 30 days) infected or non-infected foot ulcers Wagner grade 2-3
6. Receiving Negative Wound Pressure Therapy (NPWT)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Revascularization surgery on the target wound within 30 days prior to enrollment
2. Inadequate arterial supply, as evidenced by any of the following (for wounds below the knee):
1. TcOM < 30mmHg
2. ABI < 0.7 or > 1.3
3. TBI < 0.6
3. Subjects with marked immunodeficiency (HIV/AIDS, organ transplant patients and actively being treated for cancer).
4. Women who are pregnant
